rules.title: Do not offer honey to infants under 12 months
rules.summary: Honey may contain Clostridium botulinum spores that an infant gut cannot neutralise, creating a life-threatening neurotoxin risk.
do_list: Use pasteurised fruit purées or breast milk/formula as natural sweeteners in recipes for infants.
Scan labels for honey in cereals, yogurts, teething biscuits, or glazes before serving to babies.
Educate caregivers and grandparents about the 12-month rule during meal handoffs.
dont_list: No raw or cooked honey, including in baked goods, herbal remedies, or honey-lemon drinks before 12 months.
Avoid honey powder, honey-based cough syrups, and honey graham crackers aimed at toddlers when feeding infants.
rules.why: Infant gut flora and bile acids are immature; spores can germinate and produce botulinum toxin, leading to hypotonia and respiratory compromise.

how_to.title: Label audit
how_to.description: Create a shared grocery list noting honey-containing brands to avoid for the family’s infant.

how_to.title: Caregiver briefing
how_to.description: Include the honey restriction on childcare handover cards alongside allergen notes.

rules.compliance_notes: Re-evaluate at 12 months adjusted age for preterm infants with clinician guidance.

rules.title: Mix powdered infant formula with water ≥158°F/70°C for safety
rules.summary: Using hot water inactivates Cronobacter sakazakii and other pathogens that may survive in powdered formula.
do_list: Boil water and cool for no more than 30 minutes before mixing, ensuring it stays ≥158°F/70°C.
Cool prepared bottles quickly under running cold water or in an ice bath until body temperature.
Discard any unfinished feed within 2 hours of preparation (1 hour if kept at room temperature).
dont_list: Do not use bottled or room-temperature water for newborns or medically fragile infants unless directed by a clinician.
Avoid storing mixed formula in the refrigerator for more than 24 hours.
rules.why: Cronobacter infection carries high morbidity in infants under two months; hot water reduces pathogen load before feeding.

how_to.title: Thermal check
how_to.description: Use a kettle with a built-in thermometer or an instant-read probe to confirm the mixing temperature.

how_to.title: Cooling protocol
how_to.description: Place sealed bottles in an ice bath to reach feeding temperature within 10 minutes and prevent bacterial growth.

rules.compliance_notes: Preterm and immunocompromised infants may need additional sterilisation steps per NICU discharge instructions.

rules.title: Introduce peanut by 4–6 months for high-risk infants under clinical guidance
rules.summary: Early, supervised peanut introduction can reduce the risk of IgE-mediated allergy by up to 81% in high-risk infants.
do_list: Arrange an evaluation for infants with severe eczema or egg allergy before first peanut exposure.
Offer 2 grams of peanut protein (e.g., thinned peanut butter or peanut powder) three times per week during maintenance.
Document reaction signs and share an action plan with caregivers.
dont_list: Avoid whole peanuts or chunky spreads that pose choking risk.
Do not delay beyond 6 months for high-risk infants unless advised by an allergist.
rules.why: Immunologic tolerance develops when allergenic proteins are presented during the window of immune plasticity in infancy.

how_to.title: Clinic-supervised feeding
how_to.description: Schedule the first feeding in a controlled setting with epinephrine available for high-risk infants.

how_to.title: Maintenance schedule
how_to.description: Set calendar reminders for thrice-weekly peanut servings to maintain tolerance.

rules.compliance_notes: Families need individualized dosing if the child has additional food allergies or growth restrictions.

serving_forms.form: 2 tsp smooth peanut butter mixed with 2-3 tsp warm breast milk, formula, or purée until pourable
serving_forms.prep: Stir until no clumps remain; test temperature before offering on spoon.

serving_forms.form: Peanut powder whisked into oatmeal or yogurt; texture should coat the spoon but drip slowly
serving_forms.notes: Offer in seated high chair with close supervision.

serving_forms.form: Thin layer of smooth peanut butter spread on toast strips or soft pancakes

do_list: Pair with vitamin C fruit purées to support iron absorption when mixed into cereals.
Keep water nearby and pause if wet, rattly cough develops.
dont_list: Avoid crunchy or chunky peanut butter until safe chewing is established.
Do not offer peanut-containing snacks in the car seat.
foods.why: Peanuts supply plant protein and introduce allergenic proteins during the immune tolerance window.

how_to.title: Emergency readiness
how_to.description: Review symptoms of mild vs severe reactions with caregivers and store epinephrine where indicated.

foods.portion_hint: Aim for ~2 grams peanut protein per serving during maintenance (about 2 tsp peanut butter).

foods.name: Salmon (steamed & flaked)

serving_forms.form: Steam or bake boneless fillet until opaque; mash with fork and thin with breast milk, formula, or water.
serving_forms.notes: Check for pin bones by running fingers along the grain before serving.

serving_forms.form: Offer pea-sized flakes mixed with mashed avocado or yogurt.
Fork-flaked salmon cakes baked without added salt; serve beside whole grains and vegetables.
serving_forms.prep: Use eggs or mashed sweet potato as binder; cut into bite-sized pieces.

do_list: Rotate between salmon, trout, sardines, and pollock to diversify omega-3 intake.
Serve with iron-rich sides such as lentils or fortified cereals.
dont_list: Avoid high-mercury fish such as king mackerel, shark, or swordfish for toddlers.
Do not add honey glazes until after 12 months.
foods.why: Low-mercury fatty fish provide DHA for neurodevelopment and vitamin D for bone health.

how_to.description: Prepare multiple portions, cool rapidly, and store refrigerated (≤40°F) for up to 2 days.

guides.title: Starting Solids: 4-Week Evidence Framework
guides.summary: Week-by-week roadmap covering readiness cues, iron-rich starter foods, allergen rotation, and responsive feeding setup.
guides.body_md:
## Overview
Follow the infant’s developmental cues while layering iron-rich foods and early allergen exposure.

### Week 1: Skills & Iron
- Observe head control, interest in food, and ability to sit with support.
- Offer iron-fortified oatmeal mixed with breast milk/formula once daily.

### Week 2: Textures
- Add smooshable vegetables and fruits; progress from smooth to lightly mashed.
- Encourage open cup sips of water (1–2 oz/day).

### Week 3: Allergen Rotation
- Introduce peanut (per allergen rule) and cooked egg on separate days.
- Repeat tolerated allergens at least twice weekly.

### Week 4: Family Foods
- Bring baby to table meals; offer soft strips of family foods with minimal salt/sugar.
- Journal reactions, stool changes, and appetite cues for clinician review.

guides.title: Allergen Maintenance & Caregiver Playbook
guides.summary: Create and operationalise an allergen rotation across home, childcare, and extended family settings to sustain tolerance.
guides.body_md:
## Step 1: Baseline Assessment
List confirmed allergens, pending challenges, and emergency medications.

## Step 2: Rotation Calendar
Plan weekly servings for peanut, egg, dairy, tree nuts, soy, wheat, sesame, and finned fish.

## Step 3: Caregiver Training
Share reaction action plan, storage instructions, and cross-contact precautions.

## Step 4: Data Review
Sync logs monthly with clinician; adjust for illness, travel, or feeding regressions.
